sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 6221/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Cristian Cătălin Ungureanu (“the applicant”) on 25 November 2013.
2.  The applicant was represented by Ms E. Ungureanu, a lawyer practising in Ploieşti. The Romanian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Ms C. Brumar, from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
3.  The applicant alleged that it had been impossible for him to maintain personal relations with his son during the divorce proceedings, and that the length of those proceedings had been excessive.
4.  On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Ploiești.
6.  At the relevant time, he was married to I.M.U. and they had a son together, born in 2006. Following a series of conflicts between the parents concerning their son’s education, on 13 September 2012 I.M.U. filed for divorce and custody of the child. On 19 October 2012 she left the family home and took the child with her. They moved in with her parents and grandmother.
7.  On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction ( ordonanţă preşedenţială ), seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit the child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.
8.  The Ploiești District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013. It ruled that it would not be in the child’s interests to change his residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings. It also observed that the applicant had not been prevented from visiting his child in the mother’s new home, as he himself had confirmed in his statements before the court. The court noted that in any case the law did not provide for the possibility to have visiting rights established during divorce proceedings. It relied on Article 6132 of the Code of Civil Procedure (see paragraph 18 below).
9.  Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child. The court reiterated that the law did not allow for the granting of that right during divorce and custody proceedings. The court also ordered the applicant to pay 1,000 Romanian lei (RON – approximately 230 euros (EUR)) to I.M.U., representing the costs that I.M.U. had incurred. The court delivered the final decision in the case on 27 May 2013.
10.  In June 2013 the applicant, who was in the habit of visiting his son at school in the mornings, was removed from the school premises by the school guard, who informed him that from then on, he would need the school principal’s permission if he wanted to see his son at the school.
11.  According to the applicant, after the final decision of 27 May 2013 (see paragraph 9 above), I.M.U. and her family denied him any further contact with his son. It appears from the parties’ submissions that the applicant was able to see his son on 27 December 2012, between 31 December 2012 and 2 January 2013, on 20 January, between 2 and 3 March, on 14 and 17 March, on 28 April, on 2, 6 and 12 May 2013, and one last time, on 9 June 2013, after the court had given its ruling in respect of the interim injunction.
12.  On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 (see paragraph 8 above) to the case file.
13.  After several postponements that were due mainly to the parties’ requests to be allowed to submit additional evidence, on 22 January 2014 the Ploieşti District Court gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings, ruling that the child’s sole residence would be with his mother. The applicant was granted the right to have the child stay at his home every other weekend and for two weeks during the summer holidays. On 21 February 2014 the applicant asked the District Court to finish the drafting of its written judgment faster, and reiterated that he had been unable to see his child for the past ten months.
14.  On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal. On 2 April 2014 I.M.U. also lodged an appeal against the District Court’s judgment. Despite requests from the applicant to expedite the proceedings in order to allow him to re-establish contact with his son, the case file could not be sent to the Prahova County Court before 7 May 2014 owing to administrative problems within the District Court.
15.  The start of the proceedings before the Prahova County Court was postponed on several occasions in order to allow the parties to get acquainted with the submissions in the file, to hear evidence and to obtain an expert evaluation of the relations between the parents and between each parent and the child. The County Court delivered its ruling on 22 October 2015. It upheld the previous decision adopted by the District Court.
16.  Both parties lodged appeals against the County Court’s decision. At the applicant’s request, the case was sent to the Bucharest Court of Appeal. After several postponements to the proceedings, on 2 November 2016 the Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered the final decision in the case. It upheld the ruling of the District Court, but made some amendments to the applicant’s visiting schedule.
17.  On 19 February 2018 the child moved in with the applicant, at the boy’s own express request and in accordance with an agreement signed before a notary by both parents, following the mother’s decision to move permanently to another town.
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
18.  Article 6132 of the Code of Civil Procedure (“the former Code”), as applicable at the relevant time, provided that during divorce proceedings a court could order temporary measures by means of an interim injunction, concerning: custody of children, alimony, child allowance and use of the family home. The same provision was incorporated into Article 920 of the new Code of Civil Procedure, which entered into force on 15 February 2013 and is presently applicable.

The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Ploiești.
At the relevant time, he was married to I.M.U. and they had a son together, born in 2006.
Following a series of conflicts between the parents concerning their son’s education, on 13 September 2012 I.M.U. filed for divorce and custody of the child.
On 19 October 2012 she left the family home and took the child with her.

events.source_text: They moved in with her parents and grandmother.
events.event_what: Moved in with her parents and grandmother

events.source_text: On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction ( ordonanţă preşedenţială ), seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit his child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.
The Ploieşti District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013.
It ruled that it would not be in the child’s interests to change his residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings.
It also observed that the applicant had not been prevented from visiting his child in the mother’s new home, as he himself had confirmed in his statements before the court.
events.event_what: Observed that the applicant had been allowed to visit his child

events.source_text: The court also ordered the applicant to pay 1,000 Romanian lei (RON – approximately 230 euros (EUR)) to I.M.U., representing the costs that I.M.U. had incurred.

(i) EUR 8,000, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 2,380, plus any tax that may be chargeable to the applicant, in respect of costs and expenses; (b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period, plus three percentage points.

The case originated in an application (no. 6221/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Cristian Cătălin Ungureanu (“the applicant”) on 25 November 2013.

The applicant was represented by Ms E. Ungureanu, a lawyer practising in Ploieşti. The Romanian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Ms C. Brumar, from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The applicant alleged that it had been impossible for him to maintain personal relations with his son during the divorce proceedings, and that the length of those proceedings had been excessive.
On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government. 5. The applicant was born in 1972 and lives in Ploiești.

At the relevant time, he was married to I.M.U. and they had a son together, born in 2006. Following a series of conflicts between the parents concerning their son’s education, on 13 September 2012 I.M.U. filed for divorce and custody of the child. On 19 October 2012 she left the family home and took the child with her. They moved in with her parents and grandmother.

On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction (ordonanţă preşedenţială), seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit the child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.

The Ploiești District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013. It ruled that it would not be in the child’s interests to change his residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings. It also observed that the applicant had not been prevented from visiting his child in the mother’s new home, as he himself had confirmed in his statements before the court. The court noted that in any case the law did not provide for the possibility to have visiting rights established during divorce proceedings. It relied on Article 6132 of the Code of Civil Procedure (see paragraph 18 below).

Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child. The court reiterated that the law did not allow for the granting of that right during divorce and custody proceedings. The court also ordered the applicant to pay 1,000 Romanian lei (RON – approximately 230 euros (EUR)) to I.M.U., representing the costs that I.M.U. had incurred. The court delivered the final decision in the case on 27 May 2013.

Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child. The court reiterated that the law did not allow for the granting of that right during divorce and custody proceedings. The court also ordered the applicant to pay 1,000 Romanian lei (RON – approximately 230 euros (EUR)) to I.M.U., representing the costs that I.M.U. had incurred. The court delivered the final decision in the case on 27 May 2013.

Both parties lodged appeals against the County Court’s decision. At the applicant’s request, the case was sent to the Bucharest Court of Appeal. After several postponements to the proceedings, on 2 November 2016 the Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered the final decision in the case. It upheld the ruling of the District Court, but made some amendments to the applicant’s visiting schedule.

On 19 February 2018 the child moved in with the applicant, at the boy’s own express request and in accordance with an agreement signed before a notary by both parents, following the mother’s decision to move permanently to another town.

Article 6132 of the Code of Civil Procedure (“the former Code”), as applicable at the relevant time, provided that during divorce proceedings a court could order temporary measures by means of an interim injunction, concerning: custody of children, alimony, child allowance and use of the family home. The same provision was incorporated into Article 920 of the new Code of Civil Procedure, which entered into force on 15 February 2013 and is presently applicable.

The court reiterated that the law did not allow for the granting of that right during divorce and custody proceedings. The court also ordered the applicant to pay 1,000 Romanian lei (RON – approximately 230 euros (EUR)) to I.M.U., representing the costs that I.M.U. had incurred. Both parties lodged appeals against the County Court’s decision. At the applicant’s request, the case was sent to the Bucharest Court of Appeal. After several postponements to the proceedings, on 2 November 2016 the Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered the final decision in the case. It upheld the ruling of the District Court, but made some amendments to the applicant’s visiting schedule.

On 19 February 2018 the child moved in with the applicant, at the boy’s own express request and in accordance with an agreement signed before a notary by both parents, following the mother’s decision to move permanently to another town.

Article 6132 of the Code of Civil Procedure (“the former Code”), as applicable at the relevant time, provided that during divorce proceedings a court could order temporary measures by means of an interim injunction, concerning: custody of children, alimony, child allowance and use of the family home. The same provision was incorporated into Article 920 of the new Code of Civil Procedure, which entered into force on 15 February 2013 and is presently applicable.

The case originated in an application (no. 6221/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Cristian Cătălin Ungureanu (“the applicant”) on 25 November 2013.
On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government.

On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction ( ordonanţă preşedenţială ), seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit the child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.
The Ploiești District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013.
Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child.
The court delivered the final decision in the case on 27 May 2013.
On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.

After several postponements that were due mainly to the parties’ requests to be allowed to submit additional evidence, on 22 January 2014 the Ploieşti District Court gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings, ruling that the child’s sole residence would be with his mother.
On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal.

Despite requests from the applicant to expedite the proceedings in order to allow him to re-establish contact with his son, the case file could not be sent to the Prahova County Court before 7 May 2014 owing to administrative problems within the District Court.
The County Court delivered its ruling on 22 October 2015. It upheld the previous decision adopted by the District Court.

After several postponements to the proceedings, on 2 November 2016 the Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered the final decision in the case. It upheld the ruling of the District Court, but made some amendments to the applicant’s visiting schedule.

On 19 February 2018 the child moved in with the applicant, at the boy’s own express request and in accordance with an agreement signed before a notary by both parents, following the mother’s decision to move permanently to another town.

On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government.

The Ploiești District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013.
Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child.
The court delivered the final decision in the case on 27 May 2013.
On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.

After several postponements that were due mainly to the parties’ requests to be allowed to submit additional evidence, on 22 January 2014 the Ploieşti District Court gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings, ruling that the child’s sole residence would be with his mother.
On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal.

Despite requests from the applicant to expedite the proceedings in order to allow him to re-establish contact with his son, the case file could not be sent to the Prahova County Court before 7 May 2014 owing to administrative problems within the District Court.
The County Court delivered its ruling on 22 October 2015. It upheld the previous decision adopted by the District Court.

After several postponements to the proceedings, on 2 November 2016 the Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered the final decision in the case. It upheld the ruling of the District Court, but made some amendments to the applicant’s visiting schedule.

On 19 February 2018 the child moved in with the applicant, at the boy’s own express request and in accordance with an agreement signed before a notary by both parents, following the mother’s decision to move permanently to another town.

Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings;

events.source_text: In June 2013 the applicant, who was in the habit of visiting his son at school in the mornings, was removed from the school premises by the school guard, who informed him that from then on, he would need the school principal’s permission if he wanted to see his son at the school.
events.event_what: removed the applicant from the school premises and informed him that he would need the school principal’s permission if he wanted to see his son at the school.

events.source_text: On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.
events.event_what: added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.

events.source_text: After several postponements that were due mainly to the parties’ requests to be allowed to submit additional evidence, on 22 January 2014 the Ploieşti District Court gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings.
events.event_what: gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings.

events.source_text: On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal.
events.event_what: served the judgment on the applicant at his address and he lodged an appeal.

events.source_text: The Court found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings.
events.event_what: found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings.

events.source_text: The Court ordered Romania to pay the applicant EUR 8,000 (eight thousand euros) in non-pecuniary damage and EUR 2,380 (two thousand three hundred and eighty euros) in costs and expenses.
events.event_what: ordered Romania to pay the applicant EUR 8,000 (eight thousand euros) in non-pecuniary damage and EUR 2,380 (two thousand three hundred and eighty euros) in costs and expenses.

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 6221/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Cristian Cătălin Ungureanu (“the applicant”) on 25 November 2013.
The applicant was represented by Ms E. Ungureanu, a lawyer practising in Ploieşti.
The Romanian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Ms C. Brumar, from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The applicant alleged that it had been impossible for him to maintain personal relations with his son during the divorce proceedings, and that the length of those proceedings had been excessive.
events.event_what: alleged that it had been impossible for him to maintain personal relations with his son during the divorce proceedings, and that the length of those proceedings had been excessive.

events.source_text: On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government.
events.event_what: communicated the application to the Government

events.source_text: On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction ( ordonanţă preşedenţială ), seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit the child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.
events.event_what: lodged an application for an interim injunction seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit the child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.

events.source_text: The Ploiești District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013. It ruled that it would not be in the child’s interests to change his residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings.
events.event_what: ruled that it would not be in the child’s interests to change his residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings.

events.source_text: Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child.
events.event_what: following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child.

events.source_text: In June 2013 the applicant, who was in the habit of visiting his son at school in the mornings, was removed from the school premises by the school guard, who informed him that from then on, he would need the school principal’s permission if he wanted to see his son at the school.
events.event_what: removed the applicant from the school premises and informed him that he would need the school principal’s permission if he wanted to see his son at the school.

events.source_text: On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.
events.event_what: added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.

events.source_text: After several postponements that were due mainly to the parties’ requests to be allowed to submit additional evidence, on 22 January 2014 the Ploieşti District Court gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings.
events.event_what: gave its judgment on the divorce proceedings.

events.source_text: On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal.
events.event_what: served the judgment on the applicant at his address and he lodged an appeal.

events.source_text: The Court found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings.
events.event_what: found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings.

events.source_text: The Court ordered Romania to pay the applicant EUR 8,000 (eight thousand euros) in non-pecuniary damage and EUR 2,380 (two thousand three hundred and eighty euros) in costs and expenses.
events.event_what: ordered Romania to pay the applicant EUR 8,000 (eight thousand euros) in non-pecuniary damage and EUR 2,380 (two thousand three hundred and eighty euros) in costs and expenses.

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 6221/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Cristian Cătălin Ungureanu (“the applicant”) on 25 November 2013.
events.event_what: against Romania under Article 34 of the Convention

events.source_text: The application was communicated to the Government on 16 September 2014.
On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.
events.event: added a copy of the ruling

events.source_text: On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal.
The start of the proceedings before the Prahova County Court was postponed on several occasions... The County Court delivered its ruling on 22 October 2015.

On 19 February 2018 the child moved in with the applicant, at the boy’s own express request and in accordance with an agreement signed before a notary by both parents, following the mother’s decision to move permanently to another town.

FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, Declares the application admissible; Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings;
events.event: declared the application admissible and held a violation of Article 8
events.event_what: in respect of the impossibility of granting of visiting rights during divorce proceedings

events.source_text: Holds that there is no need to examine separately whether there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention also on account of the length of the divorce proceedings;
events.event: held no need to examine a separate violation of Article 8
events.event_what: on account of the length of the divorce proceedings

events.source_text: Holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final, in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, the following amounts...
events.event_what: to the applicant within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final

events.source_text: Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: dismissed the remainder of the claim
events.event_what: the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction

events.source_text: The applicant lodged an application with the Court on 25 November 2013.
On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government.
The applicant alleged that it had been impossible for him to maintain personal relations with his son during the divorce proceedings.
On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction.
events.event: lodged an application for an interim injunction
events.event_what: lodged an application for an interim injunction

events.source_text: The Ploiești District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013.
The applicant's appeal was rejected by the Prahova County Court.
The Bucharest Court of Appeal delivered its final decision on 2 November 2016.

The case originated in an application (no. 6221/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Mr Cristian Cătălin Ungureanu (“the applicant”) on 25 November 2013.
events.event_what: lodged an application against Romania under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms

events.source_text: The applicant was represented by Ms E. Ungureanu, a lawyer practising in Ploieşti. The Romanian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Ms C. Brumar, from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
events.event_when: at the time when the application was lodged

events.source_text: The applicant alleged that it had been impossible for him to maintain personal relations with his son during the divorce proceedings, and that the length of those proceedings had been excessive.
events.event_when: at the time when the application was lodged
events.event_what: alleged violation of his rights during the divorce proceedings

events.source_text: On 16 September 2014 the application was communicated to the Government.
events.event_what: communicated the application to the Government

events.source_text: Following an appeal by the applicant, that ruling was upheld by the Prahova County Court, which rejected all the arguments raised by the applicant concerning his right to visit his child. The court also ordered the applicant to pay 1,000 Romanian lei (RON – approximately 230 euros (EUR)) to I.M.U., representing the costs that I.M.U. had incurred.
events.event_what: appealed the District Court's ruling, but the Prahova County Court upheld the ruling and ordered the applicant to pay costs

events.source_text: On 4 March 2014 the judgment was served on the applicant at his address; on 28 March 2014 he lodged an appeal.
events.event_what: received the judgment and lodged an appeal

events.source_text: On 2 November 2012 the applicant lodged an application for an interim injunction (ordonanţă preşedenţială ), seeking to be granted sole or shared custody of the child during the divorce proceedings, or alternatively the right to visit the child during those proceedings according to a detailed schedule that he submitted to the court.
events.event_what: lodged an application for an interim injunction seeking custody or visitation rights during the divorce proceedings

events.source_text: The Ploieşti District Court gave its ruling on 8 January 2013. It ruled that it would not be in the child’s interests to change his residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings.
events.event_what: gave its ruling on the interim injunction application and decided not to change the child's residence temporarily during the divorce proceedings

events.source_text: In June 2013 the applicant, who was in the habit of visiting his son at school in the mornings, was removed from the school premises by the school guard, who informed him that from then on, he would need the school principal’s permission if he wanted to see his son at the school.
events.event_who: The applicant and the school guard
events.event_what: the applicant was removed from the school premises and informed that he needed permission to see his son at the school

events.source_text: On 30 October 2013 the applicant added a copy of the District Court’s ruling of 8 January 2013 to the case file.
events.event: Adding document to the case file
events.event_what: added a copy of the District Court's ruling to the case file

events.source_text: On 21 February 2014 the applicant asked the District Court to finish the drafting of its written judgment faster, and reiterated that he had been unable to see his child for the past ten months.
events.event_what: asked the District Court to finish drafting the written judgment faster and reiterated that he had been unable to see his child for ten months

events.source_text: On 4 March 2014 the applicant lodged an appeal.
events.event_what: lodged an appeal against the District Court's judgment

events.source_text: On 2 April 2014 I.M.U. also lodged an appeal against the District Court’s judgment.
events.event_what: lodged an appeal against the District Court's judgment

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 4 September 2018, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: notified the parties of the judgment in English, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court
